posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53043330
Hey, that's cool. I was just curious since the threads here always seems collector focus.

Radiant Pokemon are Pokemon that you can only have one of in your deck, but they're have powerful effects or attacks. So it's fun to try and choose which Radiant you want to use or work into your deck. Pic rel is one of the most popular ones, discard pile setup and drawing is really good for a lot of decks.

Radiant Eternatus is the main new one from CZ people like. When you bench it, you can search your deck for any two VMAX Pokemon and bench them as well. Which opens up a lot of opportunities for faster VMAX play.

>>53058196
>I was surprised people can just join games without even having the mod
The game is just a sandbox, when you sub to a workshop you're just getting a .json file telling the game to load different images, models, etc
Anybody that joins will just load the same information, the game will actually download these assets to make loading faster but if you don't want to clog your disk space turn Mod Cache off in the options.

>perhaps there should be a Steam group or something for Pokemon matchmaking
There probably is, lots of TTS discords popped up after the death of Global Chat, a shame. You could also host a lobby and post the info here so other anons can join. I don't play much these days but doing drafted/booster deck matches could be fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53060799
They took that new double battle thing Gamefreak made as a generational gimmick but forgot to actually use more than a handful of times in the main games and polished it. The NPCs have actual strategies beyond type specialty and the ai is better tuned to use them, there's a lot more variety in team compositions so you're not fighting team ___ grunts with 2-4 of the same early game poison or dark mons and their evolved forms the entire game, and they came up with tweaks, challenges, and alternate rule-sets to give the games even more variety. They assume the player is competent and let you get to it instead of bogging you down with a bunch of tutorials, instead they just quickly run through the basics and any info you need is there to read through on the side if you need a refresher but totally optional.

If story/worldbuilding is more your thing they handled that better than most pokemon games too, at least the first time around. Shadow pokemon are strong but their growth is stunted - you have to befriend and purify them before they'll level up and evolve so the whole series' point about friendship is actually reinforced by the mechanics. Wes shows a lot of character for a silent protagonist - he starts out with 2 friendship evolutions and gets called out several times for being bad at lying despite being a criminal, he's got a rougher background than "kid leaving home on his first adventure" but he's not just some edgy selfish jerk. The rest of the cast actually has a role to play in the story instead of showing up for 2 minutes never to be seen again and show character beyond just a line or two of flavor text. The plot has a couple twists that on a first playthrough might catch you off-guard if you're not paying attention but aren't coming completely from left-field for the sake of having a plot-twist. XD rehashes a lot of that and leans closer to main series level writing, but still at least a C.

Only thing they did WORSE was exploration.

>>53060713
I think this is grossly oversimplified, and that Colosseum is a more interesting game to play for a few reasons.

For one, it doesn't waste nearly as much of your time. It skips the usual minutia of teaching the player how to play Pokemon, and expects that you already do. Instead of playing as another newcomer and being taught how to play the game, Wes has his own starters in the late 20s and you jump right into the game's conflict. Our guy has gone rogue from his old gang, and we're effectively on the run. Meanwhile, the first several hours of Gen 7 are just the same old stuff, like showing you how to jump down ledges, fighting your rival, going to school...It isn't only slow and linear, it's uneventful and safe.

The Totem bosses are unique, but Colosseum features doubles everywhere. And the limited roster of shitters from Gen 2 naturally puts you at a disadvantage for team building.

And features being removed doesn't really matter because this was a spin-off game. It was beyond expectation for the game to even have an RPG mode when it could've JUST been Stadium 3 with nothing else. Gen 7 was a mainline game celebrating 20 years, so it was unfortunate for core mechanics like the PSS, DexNav, Triple Battles, etc. to be missing.

>>53062238
EXP Share is bad in a Pokemon context because of how easy it is to get overleveled.
With the old format if one of your monsters got too high of level swapping it to the back of the party was an easy way to avoid it becoming a problem.
Now, you have to totally box any monster that gets too high of level because otherwise it will continue growing.

Pokemon differs from most RPGs in that it isn't a team sport. Even in doubles and triple battles its not a team sport in the same way that say Final Fantasy is.
Its very much an individualized experience for each monster that you're raising. And pure gross level is an important determiner of damage both ways.
Compare Pokemon to something like Fossil Fighters, which heavily resembles it in many ways. That game is a 'team sport' where your team composition matters and monsters have very specific roles they work in and don't work in.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53063610
It matters in a game like Pokemon that doesn't scale encounters and is designed to be extremely accessible to all ages. Where you the player control your own difficulty substantially.
Level caps suck and are poor game design. Series that implement them are almost universally bad. And Pokemon is not a franchise that runs high levels across the board such that grinding past the level curve is impossible either. Nor is it designed to be one.

Putting something in the box and having to withdraw it later is a pointless hassle. Especially if it otherwise fulfills an important role on the team that you're leaving dormant while you avoid trivializing the game but may still need.
For example, recently playing BlazeBlack2, my Pignite sweeped Burgh and got quite overleveled for it. But, I still wanted that Fire and Fighting coverage on my team just in case. So I sat it in the back of my party where it was still useful if I really needed it, but wasn't going to continue outpacing the hack's level curve.

I don't see the point in answering your non-sequitur at the end.

posts.name: Shiny Paradox Hunting
posts.com:
Here's the code for the Union Circle if you want to join : V0M8GW We need a Violet player or two!

In a nutshell I host a picnic at the entrance of Area Zero and you can join it, we all make the same sandwich but only I provide the Herba to save you guys using yours (You will need to provide one ingredient (see pic related) relevant to the type we're trying to get and a condiment, such as salt) and that way by following which types match as seen in the pic we can get paradoxes from both games with one sandwich!

Important notes

If you find a shiny, you can save in front of it, that way if nothing else is found; when we start a new lobby after the sandwich is used up you can reset your game and catch it! This will only work for the person who spawned the shiny.

Try to avoid battling a shiny right away, if you start battle with it and try to run, it will despawn. post in the thread with directions so that someone else can get it. By doing the saving method mentioned in the previous note, two people can get the same shiny!

Best to hunt in seperate areas to avoid overlap, it's good to coordinate where you'll be hunting to help when guiding a player from the opposite version to your location.

>>53061295
There's only so many things Greninja can do, especially in two turns. So you try to account for everything going wrong as much as possible and then you build a counter. Right now the main things to worry about are:
>Greninja's Turn 0 move, popular opinions are Double Team, Taunt, Swords Dance
>Whether Greninja is Physical/Special/Mixed, most likely mixed to take advantage of STAB Gunk Shot, as well as Priority Water Shuriken
>If Greninja will carry debilitating status moves like Taunt or Haze, and if it will clear debuffs on Turn 1.

So you just try and build something that can cover as many of those options and then a better strategy can be refined after the move set comes out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53061361
Iron Hands @ Booster Energy
252HP / 252Att / 4SpD
Adamant nature
- Belly Drum
- Earthquake

Corviknight @ Mental Herb
248HP / 8Def / 252SpD
Calm nature
- Defog
- Light Screen / Reflect
- Taunt
- Screech

Turn1:
Turn 0 Swords Dance > Defense Cheer, Taunt, Reflect, Belly Drum
Turn 0 Double Team > Defog, Taunt, Reflect/Light Screen, Belly Drum

Turn 2: Screech x3, Earthquake

This set tries to account for a Turn 0 Double Team or Turn 0 Swords Dance. If the Turn 0 move is an attacking move and chooses Iron Hands, it's pretty much a rap.

The turn order is also set-up in a way that Belly Drum can go off without a hitch. The Defense Cheer on the first Corvinight mitigates the damage for the rest of the team, and the barrier goes up right before Iron Hand's turn. If the Greninja decides to Brick Break on Iron Hands to break the Light Screen/Reflect then it can't close out the kill next turn, even after Belly Drum. The only way it could reliably kill is if it simultaneously +Atk and +Sp,A nature and that's impossible. If it doesn't break the barrier, then it can no longer kill with anything barring crits.

It's not perfect by any means, but it accounts for most of what Greninja could theoretically pull off and barely crosses the damage threshold for a kill, assuming that 7* raids are still 25x HP.

The AI does a lot of heavy lifting without the definition, description, etc. It should default to correct grammar and punctuation, and they tend to be a little overly verbose in my experience. You can have something you can have conversations with with very little effort. Making the bot is basically giving it a script to follow, but it's all the same brain playing the different roles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53063941
Current state of CAI almost makes me not want to waste time on it. I'm waiting on mostly this >>53062112

As for training. 1 star bad replies and pick the reason that fits best, swipe until you get something good and keep going. You can also couch the ai's responses with actions like *you feel compelled to do x* or through (ooc) but the ooc route might make (ooc) chatter show up more. I'd say 5-10 fairly lengthy convos should be good enough if you've starred enough replies.

In the definitions add 3/4 examples of how you'd like them to chat. I feel that this really fleshes out their speech patterns

{{char}}: "Ah quite so, indubitably ol' chap.", *he say adjusting his monocle.*
END_OF_DIALOG
{{char}}: "Jolly ho!", *he yells, spinning his cane and adjusting his tophat.*

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53043105
the basic idea is
>kill all surrounding spawns without spawning target pokemon
>go stand right next to where an overworld mon will spawn, but doesnt actually spawn
>save and edge closer, restart game if you accidentally spawn it
>date skip to a clear day
>go to check summary screen of one of your pokemon and click the right thumb stick
>track the attacks
>0 = physical, 1 = special
>do this 128 times
>put this number into the program
>it will tell you how many more stick clicks you need to do in order to get to a shiny
>you need to exit the menu about 4-6 clicks early and walk forward
>once it has spawned it should be shiny when you encounter it, may need to check which pokemon you caught from the list and adjust the delay
https://github.com/LegoFigure11/swsh-overworld-rng-gui
theres a full manual on there with the tool, and theres a few youtube guides if you type in things like 'swsh overworld rng'
theres several tricks that mean you dont have to spam 4000 animations like date skipping or changing to the party menu

>>53054559
I prefer the dynamic that Grusha hates Larry because of his "normal" act, willingly disregarding all his talent and potential his whole life when some of us had ambitions we had to give up unwillingly. It adds some spice and an excuse to explore what drove them into their niches. What makes Larry feel that being a corporate drone is his only option? Does Grusha fear being chained down to the one career? I feel like they'd be terrible communicating in words, so it'd be things like sharing a love of soba or a refreshingly fast bird flight that appeals to them thinking "he's not that polar opposite from me after all". They sit silently side by side, begrudgingly at first, but neither can stay mad over a warming broth. By the time they aren't grumbling about one another everyone is confused about what happened while they weren't looking, how come those two seem almost friendly now? And then a small spat occurs and their hopes drop.

posts.com:
So like every guy that sees the dang Vaporeon post, I eventually got really curious and decided to give it a try.

I made us a really big dinner and got us an entire case of Angry Orchard. I used a whole massive bag of chicken tenders, a bottle of Chick-fil-A sauce, and created some of the most amazing loaded nacho cheese french fries you ever tasted.

You have no idea how much this Vaporeon ate. All that fried and greasy food was gobbled up by her. I'd be running to the toilet, but with acid armor this beast just took it all. I was checking something my friend sent me on Discord on my phone, and I didn't notice it used attract on me to get me to put on Family Guy on the TV. Not just any episodes, but the Family Guy Star Wars episodes. I had about a plate and a half worth of food, but while I was getting the TV set up, she gobbled up the rest of the food I made, even slurping up the leftover nacho cheese sauce.

And like you wouldn't think that is a problem. She crawls up on me and lays on my chest, I wrap my arms around her like a pillow, throw a blanket over us and we just watch Family Guy. Well .. it doesn't help she can just spam Focus Energy, which increases her chance to crit.

Every. Single. Time she laughs. Your nose flinches in discomfort. Her breath freaking stinks. It's like a mix of stew, and something you sniff while in a public bathroom. It's gross. It's uncomfortable.

A Focus Band helps prevent a Pokemon from occasionally fainting. And that with Acid armor, protects the Vaporeon. But it still lets out exhaust. Loudly. And if you thought the breath and burps were bad, this monster just ate a massive plate of fried food.

So after the first two specials when she falls asleep on you and rests, you got a farting Vaporeon pinning you down with its bad breath, that drools spit mixed with nacho cheese all over you.

Overall it was not as bad as some of my other dates, but that's not saying much. Does anyone else's Vaporeon like to watch Family Guy?

>>53019210
Depends on what you want out of it.

It IS a competitive fighting game, despite the superficially arena fighter-esque elements: The game still has unique movelists per characters, cancels, just-frames, an attack height system, etc, and the replay value still comes from playing against other people and improving rather then having a ton of modes or single player content. It is much more Street Fighter and less Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm/DBZ budokai.

That said, for a competitive fighting game, it's approachable: There's no motion inputs, everything is either a button, a button plus a direction, two buttons, or holding and releasing a button, so at a low/starting level it's easier to pick up. The way the game handles attack heights and the whole 2d-3d shift mechanic also gives players more breathing room: The phase shift mechanic means you'll never be stuck in the corner the entire match because shifts will break you out of the 2d phase and back into the 3d phase where you're on more neutral ground, and heights exist not as a way to bypass and punish blocking, but to bypass and punish other moves during their active frames, meaning as a newbie you're not worrying about blocking high or low, rather height is a tool for YOU to use when you're on the defensive to get a reversal and hit through one of your enemy's moves.

Note this does not mean that there's less depth at a higher level of play: Some combos, tech, etc top players will be using take a lot of precise timing and dexterity (Garchomp's charge input run stance cancels are as such a lot of chomp players have to change their button layout) , and the whole phase shift mechanic is actually a huge source of an adapational and resource mangement skillgap at top play where players intentionally alter their combo composition and move choices on the fly to cause or delay shifts based on what's to their advantage; and there's still height mixups even if there's not height based blocking

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53019273
>>53019210
cont:

> and there's still height mixups even if there's not height based blocking

For example, if you have a move that bypasses and punishes move of X height, and the other player knows you have that, then they can try to use a different combo starter or meaty/on wakeup move or combo ender to try to punish you trying to punish that height

Basically, while it's said so often it's a cliche, Pokken really is "Easy to learn, hard to master": The changes Pokken makes to the fighting game template targets the sort of stuff new players tend to struggle with (motion inputs, being kept in the corner, dealing with what height to block), but those changes don't actually erase the skillgap at high level play and actually add more depth when it comes to neutral (when both players are trying to get a hit in and outwit the other player), having to adapt rather then flowchart, etc: The fact shifts break you back to a neutral state and the height system enables reversals really means there's a lot more back-and-forth where both players are in the driver's seat of the match.

But like any fighting game, you'll get out what you put in: The fun comes from learning, improving, and playing matches, not from unlocks or modes.

>>53019284
Firstly, I think worrying about "is X a good character to start with" is sort of a bad approach to getting into a fighting game: If there's a character or a game you like, start playing. If you worry about getting all the resources (not that frame data, combo guides, common punishes, etc aren't good to know) or starting with an easy character, you can easily pysche yourself out and put off just playing and learning the game/character you actually wanna play.

That being said, he actually is I think one of the easiest characters to start with. He has relatively short combos and just needs like a few stray grabs or short combos or single hits to do big damage. The drawback is he can struggle to get in to land those hits.

>>53019485
The phase shift system is entirely predictable/under the player's control, the tutorial just doesn't explain it.

3d > 2d shifts happen on basically any heavy hit or with most specials. Some lights cause it too. Basically, anything other then light projectiles will shift from 3d to 2d. This is why the game is more a 2d fighter then a 3d one: The 3d phase is basically just an additional buffer layer of neutral play.

2d > 3d shifts occur when the PSP guage is filled, and different moves, on hit, will add more or less points to that guage. Combos that hit 21 hits long also always auto-shift (as an anti-infinite mechanic), as does the universal grab (but not command grabs). However, the guage isn't in the UI, it's something you have to learn and memorize if you wanna keep track of it.

At high level play, players will alter their combos as the match goes on to always end on shifts to do optimum damage vs the shift interrupting the combo. Or they may intentionally go for combos or moves that maybe do less damage or aren't as safe, but that add less PSP, so shifts DON'T happen (thereby keeping the other player in the corner and under pressure, and maybe to get the chance to land an additional combo for more damage in that phase in the long term) or for combos that maybe don't do as much damage but do EXTRA PSP to shift faster, in case they wanna get out of pressure themselves or get the meter/health regen causing a shift gives you. Some moves also reduce or reset the PSP guage.

But like when you're starting out, I wouldn't worry about it that much: Just remember universal grabs always auto shift, heavy hits in the 3d phase shift to 2d, and the more hits you land in 2d the faster you shift to 3d. As it applies to machamp, you should also remember your command grabs do NOT add PSP, so you can use then in the 2d phase as much as you want, and wake up slap REDUCES the guage, allowing you to keep the enemy in the 2d phase longer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019666
>allowing you to keep the enemy in the 2d phase longer.

Just in case it's not obvious, the reason you want this is because Machamp is a lot better in the 2d phasr then the 3d phase.

Machamp is slow, and is his 3d phase projectiles suck. It's very difficult for machamp to win the field phase and cause the 3d > 2d shift, and he can't do much damage while in the 3d phase.

But even stray hits or single grabs in the 2d phase by machamp do insane damage. It's still hard to actually approach the enemy though, so once machamp IS up close in the 2d phase or especially when you've got the other character in the corner, it's in your interest to keep them there and to continue to land command grabs and rack damage up without causing a shift, most of the time, because it's hard to get back to that position.

In practice, tho, there are obviously situations where you may wanna giove up your advantagious position to land a combo rather then a command grab even if it shifts and allows the enemy to escape: Maybe you aren't comfortable yourself at the moment and just wanna take the damage you can get, maybe you'd really benefit from the extra meter causing a shift brings, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019666
>>53019685
Also also, to be clear, the PSP guage works indepedently for both players.

If you land like 4 hits and almost max out the PSP guage, the enemy landing a hit won't shift: each person has their own guage.

And again, there is no actual visible guage you can look at, sadly: You either need to remember the PSP value of each move, or just reemerge "if I use X move Y times, it will shift" or "If I use Z combo and then land Y move, that will be enough to shift" etc

>>53063734
Dondozo is an answer, not a threat.

It good because it beats boosting physical attackers. Anything trying to sweep with Bulk Up or Swords Dance is hard stopped. Even non-boosting physical mons like choice band users still struggle with it. If Phys Def Dondozo is taking a special hit, its probably because you've already lost and you're just letting your opponent sweep rather than forfeiting. In 6v6 you'll almost always be in a position to easily switch Dondozo into physical attackers, and out of special attackers. Switching is a bit costlier in other formats, but very free in 6v6.

Dondozo can even max its SpD to take decently strong special hits in an attempt to wall entire teams, its HP is so high its low SpD doesn't let it down. It's still a good set all its own, so medium-strength special attackers aren't an automatic solution to Dondozo either if you end up vs this set.

>Why was the chief repeating this again?

>"Gotta say, you did one helluva job on that house."
>"That aura sphere a'yours demolished that wall, hoo boy."
>He tapped the photograph of the aftermath, as if you needed a reminder.
>The whole side of the house was blown inward.
>"Exactly three point two seconds later, you KO'd his pet umbreon and had the man in a headlock."
>The chief shook his head dismissively.
>"Good thing you didn't snap the poor lad's neck."
>You winced at the thought of killing an innocent man.
>It's your fault.
>You trusted command got the address right without double-checking.
>"Well, missy, let's all say a big thank you to the big man upstairs, 'cause nothin' short of a miracle just happened."
"Sir?" The timid Lucairo replied.
>"This was nothing short of a slam dunk case against us. No lawyer could've messed this up if they tried."
>"Turns out, Mr. Anon's a very forgiving man."
>For the first time in weeks, your ears perked up in hope.
>"Won't bore you with the legalese, but here's the jist of it."
>"The man could've bankrupted the department twice over, but all he's asking for are some repairs and remodeling. And paying the pet's poke-center bill too."
>"That is, on one condition. And that's why you're here."
>You sat up straighter, eager to help.
>"Bizarre as it may seem, you're our bargaining chip."
>"He insisted you keep your job, first off."
>"Can't say the same for others involved in this clown show."
>"Second, he wants to get to know you better."
>"Wants you to train him, can you believe it?"
>"Says he wanted to meet you a couple hours each day to exercise. And it could only be you."
>You said a silent 'thank you' to Arceus.
>"Now, look, the whole deal rides on this. Made it damn clear there's no alternative."
>"We're all losing our jobs if you don't do it."
>"Now, I can't make you..."
>You didn't hesitate. You nodded furiously.
>"Atta girl."
>"Here's his new address."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53050516
Cyclizar simply would not be banned if it didn't have regenerator. Orthworm would probably not be banned yet, but looking for a suspect if it did have regenerator.

Orthworm's stats suck but still has enough utility with hazards and phys bulk to where adding regenerator would put it on the chopping block. Shed Tail is not broken in a vacuum, and Baton Passing took so long to be banned literally because people wanted to preserve fair, balanced interactions like drypassing and subpassing compared to speedpass. A move that takes a exceedingly fair and relatively low power strategy and makes it much more efficient is not broken. Combining it with an ability that removes all the risk and cost of that move does. Cyclizar isn't broken for enabling strong pseudo-baton pass strategies, its for being able to do it at zero risk the entire game, multiple times per game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53050629
Orthworm with Regenerator would be used even more than Cyclizar because of
>Stealth Rock resistance
>Low speed meaning slow pivots, protecting the substitute's integrity
>Can hazard stack when predicting a powerful hit so your turn isn't wasted
>Very hard to OHKO physically, can always come back later at a more opportune time
>Doesn't give a shit about status

Orthworm is shit, but Orthworm with Regenerator would be even better than Cyclizar.

Ursaluna hits really hard, but that's not really an accomplishment in this meta. Yes, it OHKOs/2HKOs the entire cast, but Gen 9 is pure hyper offense. Stall is nowhere to be seen, and Ursaluna is liable to be blown the fuck open by the other hundreds of offensive menaces that plague the game currently.

>252 SpA Choice Specs Gholdengo Make It Rain vs. 0 HP / 0 SpD Ursaluna: 360-424 (89.7 - 105.7%) -- 37.5% chance to OHKO
>252 Atk Choice Band Meowscarada Flower Trick vs. 252 HP / 0 Def Ursaluna on a critical hit: 440-522 (94.8 - 112.5%) -- 68.8% chance to OHKO
>252 Atk Great Tusk Close Combat vs. 252 HP / 0 Def Ursaluna: 378-446 (81.4 - 96.1%) -- guaranteed 2HKO after burn damage
>+1 252 Atk Protosynthesis Tera Flying Roaring Moon Acrobatics (110 BP) vs. 0 HP / 0 Def Ursaluna: 354-417 (88.2 - 103.9%) -- 25% chance to OHKO
>252+ Atk Choice Band Slither Wing Close Combat vs. 0 HP / 0 Def Ursaluna: 636-750 (158.6 - 187%) -- guaranteed OHKO

It's a more extreme Slither Wing. Slower, hits a bit harder, and is considerably bulkier in return. Slither Wing also shits all over defensive Pokemon with its fat damage, but it hardly sees any use because Stall is fucking dead.

posts.com:
Anybody got any cute stories about how Latias or Altoshipping impacted their actual life?

One Halloween I dressed a bit like Latias, complete with wings and a hat of her likeness and went to work. My co-workers were mostly older people and they all thought I was a devil. lmao Only one supervisor guessed I was a Pokemon! Haha. I was so proud of her, even though she didn't know which.

That night I visited my Mom at the cancer hospital and I remember feeling a bit embarrassed because it was such a serious, somber place. I had to get let in by a security guard too while in costume. My Mom and my Dad loved it though and were happy to see me. Halloween was my Mom's favorite holiday so I'm happy that it made her smile.

After she passed, I convinced my Dad to give me her wedding ring. I keep it in my Pokemon Heroes DVD box; close to planewaifu so I'll never forget where it is or misplace it. :) Maybe someday I'll find a girl as special as Latias and be able to give it to her. :3

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It didn't. At the time it was the most successful Videogame adaptation, and the first time I'd genuinelyagree with the notion that the "videogame movie curse" had been broken.

It didn't try to re-imagine the world or lore or story of Pokémon, it simply presented a sincere cinematic adventure set in the Pokémon world.

The reason it doesn't get talked about as much is for a few reasons.

It was a standalone story with a clear ending, and thus despite some whisperings that another live action movie was in the works, absolutely nothing seemed to actually be planned or in production.

The Sonic movie gained widespread attention due to the redesign drama. The Sonic franchise course-corrected into game-accurate depictions, which truly came into fruition in the sequel with an Idris-voiced Knuckles, Game VA-Tails, and even game-specific lore and mechanics down to collecting the 7 Emeralds for Sonic to turn Super.

Then the Mario movie "broke the internet" with its game-accurate visuals, in spite of the fact that anybody with a brain can see it's entirely soulless OOC illumination trash. It just has a pleasant and nostalgic aesthetic. But the Mario movie presented the discourse that it was the first true good videogame adaptation due to it looking like the game, even in spite of the characterization.

But despite Sonic winning the heart of fans, and the Mario movie "looking" like a game, Detective Pikachu is still by far the most sincere attempt to bring a videogame world to the big screen, with the most attempt at actually being an interesting and digestible movie with cinematic flair in its own right. From the Neon Noir aesthetic, to the grandiose Torterra garden.

I will continue to hold Detective Pikachu in the highest regard as a videogame movie.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53059087
Make sure you're playing as tank and not attacker. Your job as mammo is to block goals and CC enemies for the attacker. You don't need XP or levels, you need hitpoints. Make a hitpoint focused emblem that is mostly white with some orange, black and whatever will fit. And by hitpoint focused I mean use emblems that are +HP-spAtk.

Defense and SpDef emblem stats are unimportant as they scale much stronger with your level and are diminishing returns. Focus band on defenders is great early game, but late game you'd be better off with a bonus HP item.

Overall your job as Mammo is to deny the enemy XP and score stacks and to use CC to secure kills made by the attacker. You're not the carry, your job is to feed the carry.

Also roam enemy jungle, you can steal their buffs.

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Please provide references in ONE image, especially when requesting something outside of the Pokémon universe. If you request something from the old Drawthread or a separate thread, COPY & PASTE the actual request instead of posting a link.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

>>53029037
I get where you're coming from but it's just excuses, we both know even if you had all your responsibilities removed, your wrist magically healed and were put in an environment where you had nothing to do for entertainment except draw you'd find a reason why you wouldn't.

It's ironic that you mention "retarded drunk child's doodles" because what do you think people think of me? It's just another way to rationalize not drawing so you don't have to face the opinions of other people.

I don't say all this to be an asshole or feed the self-deprecation cope, you can change; you just have to take the first step and trust that the resources and people you surround yourself with can help you be the best artist you can be.

It might come off as a cope to some since i'm seen as a "bad" artist but i think i've made some cool things over the years that wouldn't have existed had i not made a leap of faith.

You just have to believe that one day you're going to be able to fight in the same arena as these people. Thank you for listening to my ted talk.

Here we are, months later. Nobody has figured out how to get this damn thing.

- There's supposedly a requirement of 200 Happiness according to Serebii and sites parroting them. I've had Pokemon gain it that were barely at or over the limit, but there's at least one other requirement because I have dozens of 'mons at full Happiness who haven't gotten it.
- Nothing to do with walking or Let's Go mode. Tested and confirmed, despite "common knowledge" on Twitter, I've had 'mons get it without having ever taken a step outside their ball.
- Nothing to do with raids. Again, tested and confirmed, only one of my raid Pokemon have it and most of the others who do have never even seen a raid.
- Happiness and Friendship are a single mechanic and have been for several generations now.
- EVERYBODY has a story about "well, I have a Pokemon with the mark and I did this, so..." that doesn't actually help because there's no evidence.
- One of my dedicated 'mons who I've kept on my team almost the entire game doesn't have it. One I bred and fed candies to then spent 5 minutes EV training does.

It might legitimately just be random.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I had this dream last night. I don’t really play a lot of Pokémon, and I just come to /vp/ every now and again, so it was kinda weird to have it out of nowhere. In the dream I was out eating dinner with some friends when an old waiter came over and said “you look sad,” I didn’t really know what he was talking about as I was having a good enough time so I just said “nope, I’m doing alright.” He then gave a melancholy smile and said “would you like to see something interesting?”

At that point I was a bit weirded out, but my friends said they’d go and I figured why not. When led us to the front door of the restaurant, opened it, and we walked out into a much more colorful world. Not like somebody turned up the RGB, but colorful in a way I had forgotten. I looked down and I was 10 years old again, I looked at my friends and they were too. The world surrounding us was like the world 20 years ago, but only in the most wholesome, beautiful way. I turned around, and the restaurant had been turned into a Pokémon center and there were various pidgy’s in the trees and rustling in the bushes of other Pokémon you could just catch glimpses of. The atmosphere felt like something from gen 1 or 2, but in the most real, tangible way.

I looked up some steps to the Pokémon center, and there was the old waiter, but now he was 20 years younger. I walked up and asked him what happened, and what was this place. He said something along the lines of “you’ll only be here for a short while, enjoy it while you can.” So me and my friends ran around with the carefree attitude of a child just taking it all in, but all the while there was that sneaking anxiety of knowing we were on a time limit and this could be over soon. We had just gotten to a Pokémon themed casino, when I woke up.

I don’t know why but the whole thing has left me in a melancholy mood.

I've never been so heabily conflicted on a Pokemon game. SV is both the best and worst of Pokemon. For instance, the divide between "overworld" and "battle world" is gone, seeing the battles just happen where they happen ajd not in some sort of theoretical space is super cool. Same with Pokemon being out and about, alive and occupying the world. On the other hand it was so rushed snd runs so so badly that it SHOULD be getting the flak that FO76 did. The adventurous soirit is back, but it kind of felt the strongest only right at the beginning and end. The towns and cities all feel sort of half baked due to the total removal of interiors. I don't think they meant to remove interiors though. I think they just didnt have time to finish them or make them. Hence why only fucking Subway, Gyms, and the Academy have them. If they uust gave the games another year to bake or something we would have an astounding game on our hands.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Many people have National Park, Azalea Town or Ecruteak City as their most emotional/nostalgic music from Gen 2, but for me it's Violet City. The way Go Ichinose used broken chords to give the illusion that more voices are being played, while adhering to the 3-poly limit of the GB soundchip, is nothing short of impressive.

Just right at the beginning of the track, you can hear the Emaj7 - D#m7 - C#m7 - Fdim - Bmaj - F#maj progression and it hits you right in the feels. And that move to the parallel minor key by using the bVII to move from the tonic to the bVI is just absolutely lovely. And let's not forget to mention that infamous IV V iii vi that is used in the B section of the track. It's just pure love to my ears.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4zyXmnvnZ0k
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OA1l8mqfld8

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53042152
If i had to compare the 2:

Crystal clear: gen 2 taken to it's limit in terms of features, giving the player as many options as possible to explore the world (variable level gyms, being able to trade evolve mons without having to connect outside, being able to progress in any direction you want, fully visible pokemon stats etc.)

Polished crystal: Gen upgraded with up to gen 7 features in a way that doesn't harm what made gen 2 good. I would recommend it for people who started with more recent games and want to experience classic johto without having to deal with obsolete/unbalanced mechanics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53041903
Instead of 2.2.0 I'd recommend picking up the latest nightly release of 3.0.0 beta from the project's GitHub, comes with more QoL features like modernized Box GUI

https://github.com/Rangi42/polishedcrystal

Or you can check out the 9bit fork, which expands the possible number of Pokemon in the Pokedex beyond vanilla rom's limit of 254-ish monsters. However it's less stable than the beta from above, expect to run into glitches if you choose to play this one.

https://github.com/Rangi42/polishedcrystal/tree/9bit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I know this is a coomer thread but reminder that Pokken is actually a good game and you should play it

>Roster It covers nearly every type and a variety of body shapes and popularity levels (shillmons like lucario, pika, zard; popular mons like Gardevoir, Blaziken, Garchomp; more niche favorites like Weavile, Chandelure, Scizor, etc)
>Characters are highly varied in terms of playstyles, both in the sense that two players can play the same character very differently, and that they have varied kits and mechanics (IE braixen and her support cancels/building tools, Aegislash's parry and stance changes and the extra just-frames and buffs you get the more you switch, etc)
>Great balancing, basically every single character is viable in high level play, even characters in low tier still make top 8's all the time
>Mechanics that encourage fundamentals and neutral play where both players are doing mindgames and are trying to get a hit in, such as attack heights functioning as a way for moves to bypass each other and act as reversals, and the 2d-3rd phase shift system causing a return to neutral after shifts and encouraging you to mix up your combo composition and move choices based on if shifting or staying in the current phase is more to your advantage
>Online is still decently active, community still runs tons of events, stuff is centralized around discord.gg/pokken and the supercombo page, no need to join like 12 different servers

I can also give a writeup more specifically aimed at existing fighting game players, but this does touch on some of that already.

I think it would probably be better to go with HOME images, since those would be more consistent especially since sprites are no longer guaranteed for all Pokemon and would otherwise have to get sprites from fan edits which could have varying degrees of quality depending on which ones are chosen.

As far as structuring the dex, the basic approach would be to simply list how many Pokemon you want in the dex and then be able to drag and drop Pokemon into the dex. You could add nuances like being able to select an entire evolutionary line or having the dex include inbuilt options for Starters, Regional Birds, Bugs, Rodents, Fossils, Psuedos, etc.

Maybe clicking on the Pokemon images will change them between forms and regional variants or have an option that includes regional variants as separate Pokemon for dexes where perhaps you'd want both to appear.

Maybe include a "Blank" space where user can input their own fakemon although that'd more so be a bonus. You could also have types appear on the Pokemon, maybe have four options; No Types shown, Type Colours as Background, Type Titles and Type Icons, the caveat there would be then that the fakemon option would need to be developed out to be able to customize which types appear on it.

posts.com:
It is nice to know what we are getting (or not getting, as tends to be the case with modern releases) with each game but the internet, leakers and hackers have robbed the games of their mystery and magic.

Back in the early days you had no way to verify any of this bullshit without trying it for yourself. And Mew turned out to exist, so anything was possible.

In my school, the rumour was that if you used strength on the infamous truck, you'd reveal a staircase to the Silph Co. fountain (no idea why there) where you'd catch Mewthree.

I actually started a new save and traded a Pokémon with cut over to skip the SS Anne. My heart skipped a beat when I saw the truck was real, but... Strength did nothing.

Good times.

As a lifelong Pokeshipper, this whole thing has just been so surreal to me, I don’t even know how to feel.

Misty was my first cartoon crush when I was a little boy and the OS was airing new episodes in America. Their hints really made me want to see her happy and for them to get together, but it was such an engaging ship precisely because there were so many obstacles between them. Neither of the two would be honest if given the chance and all of their hints were such cockteases with no release. It didn’t help that 2BA Master came out and (in my mind at the time) completely verified my suspicions that Misty really wanted to confess but couldn’t find the courage but that dynamic just led me to ship it harder and harder as I rooted for her.

Eventually they split up and I was heartbroken, and not long after that Pokemon had its first Dexit with Gen 3 and I felt abandoned and left behind by the company. I eventually found my way back to Pokemon through the games (shipping is not all I care about in Pokemon), but I felt burned by the anime and never really kept up (I did eventually find and like Electric Tail/Pokemon Special and liked those though). Every time Misty came back I would check in out of interest, but it was just like seeing an old friend and then I’d leave the anime again.

Now, remarkably, she’s a main character again in the final arc and they’re literally teasing people like me directly after I thought I (and they) got over it. Pokeshipping has been a sad ship to bear for so long, that I’m trying to not even get my hopes up, but its crazy that I’ve even been given the chance to hope. If it does end up happening, it’ll be a twenty year release and my child self will see something he cared so much about back then, I don’t know how I’ll feel about it. If it doesn’t happen, that’s okay, I’m just happy I got the chance to dream just one more time before he hangs up his hat for good.

posts.com: I'm excited and nervous about starting Emerald after finishing Crystal. Do you guys particularly concerned with Natures/Abilities/EVs or do you just roll with the punches?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53027277
Depends on the encounter and game state, some pokemon become liabilities with a bad nature, IVs, and movepool; like -SpA Ralts with poor SpA IVs. While fine as a Gardevoir later on due to the huge Base Stat it won't be strong enough to get there as a normal party member considering it's after the fourth badge. Then at the point where you could level it up to use it, you'll have access to other pokemon, hopefully ones with better stat distributions.

Some notable ones with the issue are
>Treecko
The worst starter in terms of early-mid game
>Poochyena
Without a decent Atk/SpA, won't do enough damage until you it before Wattson. Has Howl but is way too frail to use it. Mightyena has some utility however.
>Beautifly
Too weak and limited in moves to handle poor offensive stats
>Lombre and Nuzleaf
They need stats to balance out their awful movepools
>Ralts
As stated above

Then there's the inverse
>Mudkip and Torchic
Decent moves, coverage, and resistances balance out poor stats
>Zigzagoon
Has pick Up and gets early Headbutt which is a STAB 70 power move with a flinch chance, that with Sand-Attack, Tail Whip and Growl gives a way to set up for other pokemon
>Taillow and Wingull
Access to early Wing Attack and Water gun, respectively, are extremely useful and strong.
>Dustox
It doesn't rely on its stats as it's focused on status and support

the little girl at the top of the department store no long gives you Ice Beam, Tri Attack, and Rock Slide. She now gives you Reflect, Light Screen, and Safeguard. Ice Beam TMs are at the Gamecorner you have to grind for, Tri Attack isn’t a TM anymore, and Rock Slide is a Tutor Move you need to talk to a specific NPC inside Rock Tunnel to learn. At least the slots aren’t rigged this time around.

If you want to use Wigglytuff as a special attacker: I hope you’re good at slots.

This one cut a little closer than it should have, but 10th game in the challenge is done

Lorelei and Bruno were dealt with Calm Mind sweeps from Slowbro, then instead of risking it through the status effects that Agatha tried to put me through, I pulled out Substitute Raticate. Deny status effects then sweep with Shadow Ball

Things didn't go as planned vs Lance, though. Blogpost incoming
>lead Butterfree to sleep Gyarados so Slowbro can setup
>Gyarados immediately wakes up
>to kill Gyarados and the incoming Dragonair but now Slowbro is at 1/3
>swap to Nidoking
>ice beam city
>freezes Dragonite
>promptly thaws and kills Nidoking with a crit Outrage
Ninetales dealt the final blow but that sucked, now I'm missing a lot of coverage and bulk vs Rival

>lead Raticate vs Pidgeot
>TWave then set up sub on Sand Attack
>kill with Return
>kill Alakazam with Shadow Ball
>Exeggutor comes in and TWave'd
>switch Slowbro and Calm Mind twice
>Ice Beam the eggs
>Gyarados comes in
>crits Bite twice
>leaves me at 20 HP
>in a panic, misplay and switch out, should have just sacrificed him for a free switch
>send out Butterfree
>Toxic then Protect/Psychic until we're both in the red
>predict his Full Restore and put him to sleep in the same turn (felt really good about this one)
>swap into Raticate and set up another sub, then kill with Return
>Charizard comes out and Fire Blasts the sub away
>swap into Ninetales and absorb his next Fire Blast with Flash Fire
>for some reason it Fire Blasts again while I confuse and slowly chip it with HP Electric
>Rhydon comes in
>can't safely switch into anything since Rock Tomb or EQ will kill
>confuse and burn before going down
>send out Raticate
>sub for safety and kill with Return

I had plenty of misplays (including not bringing a 6th to E4) but some of my predictions left me feeling really good, and I can't feel too bad by going all the way with Raticate and Butterfree lol. Rest easy, Mr. Nido and Azsakano.

posts.com: Why would you ever want to remove a vitamin

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53054649
Vitamins only benefit the pokemon when it is hatched.
What good is a vitamin on a pokemon, if you don't hatch that egg anymore?
It doesn't do anything but change the time, and points you get from hatching pokemon.

Meaning removing it, won't do anything to the pokemon's stats, unless you want to start hatching the eggs again.

Its good they allow you to reallocate it to a pokemon of which can make better use of it for your hatching habits.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This franchise easily has the money to put the national Dex in the games. They were very proud about supposedly future proofing it back in gen 7 when they spoke about the high poly models they created in preparation for coming generations.

I don't think anybody expects the entire dex to be catchable in-game. That hasn't been possible since gen 1. Even gen 2 required you to transfer a few Pokémon up. Then there was the whole gen 3 dexcut but that was for very different reasons.

The reason gen 8 did not make the entire dex accessible for the first time was presumably a cost cutting measure, like everything else lacking in those games. And the usual shills and sycophants rushed to play defense and started #ThankYouGamefreak on Twitter, giving them all the justification they needed to exclude the dex in future games too. The high sales sealed the deal.

As an added bonus, this now means that they can sell batches of older Pokémon back to you as DLC AND they can force those who want to transfer living Pokédexes or certain Pokémon to pay for Pokémon Home subscriptions as missing Pokémon now cannot be stored on a current gen game cart. Not to mention that a subscription service is now required to transfer Pokémon between generations at all, where it was free before. Hell, with the internal memory on 3DS and the Switch, Bank and Home were technically never necessary as a transfer medium.

And why was it necessary to move from the $5 per year Bank, which was supposed to be the future-proof storage/transfer solution to the $15 p/a Home again? Did they even try to justify it?

In short, we continue to pay far more, and get far less, and the games continue to break sales records and have people desperately run to defend it all.

At this point I do not think the national dex is ever coming back. The best we can hope for is maybe getting it as paid DLC, but I am not holding my breath. But we are not obligated to like it or gaslight ourselves into thinking it is good.

posts.com:
Mr. Jacq gives out the certificate for Pokédex completion, but wait a second! Why does he know about the other paradox Pokémon?!?

Think through all the other regions. Every other region prior either explicitly showed that all legendaries technically existed in your home universe or it was at least possible.

Using the most current versions of each region:

Kanto: No version exclusive legendaries.
Johto: No version exclusives legendaries.
Hoenn: Version exclusives clearly exist in your home universe.
Sinnoh: Version exclusives clearly exist in your home universe.
Unova: Version exclusives clearly exist in your home universe.
Kalos: Version exclusives clearly exist in your home universe.
Alola: The main legendaries clearly exist in your home universe. No reason all the ultra beast couldn’t exist in your universe.
Galar: Version exclusives clearly exist in your home universe.
Hisui: All Pokémon are catchable in your home universe.
Paldea: The version exclusive paradox mons only exist in your universe based on the time machine pulling from either the past or the future.

So, either the lore is completely a paradox or there is something big we haven’t been told. What are they hidding?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I just want a game that looks and feels like this. Is that too much to ask for?

I really hate how "plonked in" the towns/cities feel in SV. Like, Medali is just a small square settlement that's supposed to feel like a city, but it's just some roads and buildings plonked in the middle of nowhere with no thought. The outer road just cuts off into the grass as soon as it reaches the end of the buildings. Same with Cascaraffa, Cortondo, Velincia etc. They don't feel part of the world. It's like GF was worried kids wouldn't be able to tell where the cities start and end or something so they tried to make it really obvious. The only that kind of makes sense is Montenevera.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My dream Pokemon game is one where you can choose an occupation in the Pokemon world and have a fully fleshed out storyline to go with it. Some of the occupations would be the trainer classes, and some would be new stuff, all with some kind of gameplay element tied to them that gets you resources that you can trade with other players.
Imagine becoming a Pokemon chef and you battle your rival for ingredients, or working as a Pokemon Ranger and defending wild Pokemon from invasive species, or studying to become a Pokemon doctor and helping your classmate evolve her Chansey, or something--obviously the regular "become the champ" thing is still there but that'd be the 'main' story. The games love to give gym leaders and E4 memebers jobs and places in the world, imagine working alongside an E4 member for like, a cooking quest, then they call you out when you challenge them later. Stuff like that would be so cool and help the world and its chracters feel connected and alive.
It'd be like Fantasy Life, or I guess FFXIV for a more mainstream game...

Anyway that'll never happen so I want NatDex and fully fledged contests back. Megas too, fuck it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53060450
in RBY it was explained that when pokemon see your badges, they respect you and listen to you.
that's why for the longest time, as a child, i thought that even your own pokemon would disobey you if you raised them too much at first (this was reinforced by the anime and Ash's Charizard). i still remember misty saying "now that you have the cascade badge all pokemon up to level 30 will obey you!" and then giovanni says something like "all pokemon will obey you without question now that you have my badge!"
turns out this was wrong - all pokemon you catch obey you.
however i think this would be a natural way to prevent overleveling. i think it would be to artificial to do level scaling or basing levels on how many badges you have.
rather, i think pokemon should just stop obeying you past a certain level without enough badges - until of course you earn the last badge, when everyone obeys you.
